label: AB3C_oC10_38_a_ae_b-002
title: Orthorhombic BaTiO$_{3}$ Structure
comments:
The perovskite BaTiO$_{3}$ undergoes a variety of temperature driven phase transitions. (Shirane, 1957) 
 The first three structures are ferroelectric: \begin{itemize} \item Below 193K the structure is \href{current_web_home_dir/AB3C_hR5_160_a_b_a-001}{rhombohedral}. \item Between 193K and 278K the structure is orthorhombic. (This structure) \item Between 278K and 393K the structure is \href{current_web_home_dir/AB3C_tP5_99_b_ac_a-001}{tetragonal}. This is the room-temperature form of the material. \item Above 393K the compound is a \href{current_web_home_dir/AB3C_cP5_221_a_c_b-001}{cubic perovskite ($E2_{1}$)}. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 \href{current_web_home_dir/AB3C_hP30_194_bf_hk_af-001}{Hexagonal BaTiO$_{3}$} can be stabilized by alloying the titanium sites with other transition metals. (Dickson, 1961) The pure structure has been grown at 1853K and cooled to room temperature. (Akimo, 1994) 
 The data for this structure was taken 263K. 
 Space group $Amm2$ \#38 does not specify the origin of the $z$-axis.  We set it by taking $z_{1} = 0$, putting the barium atom at the origin.
